For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"quantum metric\" and \"ssh chain\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm 3 different ways the two given concepts could be connected in a Pytheus-compatible target.\n    1. \u201cTopologically-protected teleportation\u201d \u2013 implement a four-site SSH chain as a linear-optical entanglement-swapping network. Alternate \u201cstrong\u201d (intracell) and \u201cweak\u201d (intercell) couplings by specifying only certain pair-source connections. Perform Bell measurements at the two interior nodes (ancilla detectors) to herald a Bell pair between the two end modes, and study how the teleportation fidelity reflects the SSH topological invariant (edge versus bulk coupling patterns).\n    2. \u201cQuantum metric mapping via entanglement swapping\u201d \u2013 build a small SSH chain where one tunes a parameter \u03b8 that continuously interpolates between trivial and topological phases (by reweighting interferometer reflectivities). Use pairs of entangled photons as probes, swap entanglement along various length scales, and extract the Fubini-Study metric in \u03b8 space by measuring output-state overlap variations via Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel-type measurements. The target becomes a network that implements the swap-and-overlap protocol.\n    3. \u201cMulti-path SSH routing of entanglement\u201d \u2013 generalize entanglement swapping to a two-dimensional SSH lattice of four modes arranged in two dimers. Use beam-splitter couplings (with removed_connections to enforce SSH connectivity) and ancilla detectors to route entanglement from one corner to the opposite. Then measure the quantum metric of the routing channel by comparing different routing paths.\n\n  Step 2: Check novelty & Pytheus obstacles.\n    1. Novel: no prior entanglement-swapping experiment has encoded SSH topology to protect/characterize teleportation. Feasible: only pair sources + linear optics + ancilla detectors, no hyper-entanglement or feedback.\n    2. Interesting but Pytheus cannot natively parameter-tune continuous reflectivities or compute metric overlaps.\n    3. Too complex: multi-path SSH lattice might exceed Pytheus\u2019s search space.\n\n  Step 3: Pick idea 1 as most promising.\n\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it directly fuses the SSH topological-chain concept with multi-node entanglement-swapping to realize a \u201ctopologically protected\u201d teleportation channel, never before addressed in linear-optical networks.\n\n  Step 5: This idea is feasible in the pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because:\n    \u2022 It\u2019s a pure quantum network (entanglement swapping \u2192 teleportation).\n    \u2022 It uses only probabilistic photon-pair sources, linear optics, and post\u2010selection.\n    \u2022 No dynamic feedback or cavities are required.\n    \u2022 The target is a Bell state between the two end modes, heralded by ancilla detectors at the interior nodes.\n    \u2022 Connectivity is enforced via removed_connections, encoding the alternating SSH pattern.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for the Expert. We simulate a four-site SSH chain via a linear-optical entanglement-swapping network. \u2028By constraining which pair sources can emit to which modes, we enforce the alternating \u201cintracell\u201d (0\u20131, 2\u20133) and \u201cintercell\u201d (1\u20132) couplings of the SSH model. Bell measurements at modes 1 and 2 then teleport (swap) entanglement from the left boundary (mode 0) to the right boundary (mode 3). Heralding on the two ancilla detector clicks implements a teleportation channel\u2014effectively a Bell state\u2014between modes 0 and 3. Varying the connectivity or ancilla patterns will let one probe the topological protection of this teleportation.\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to create a maximally entangled state |\u03a6+> = |00>+|11> (without normalization) between end modes 0 and 3, using only probabilistic photon-pair sources and linear optics. No single emitter sends to more than two nodes. Two interior nodes (1 and 2) serve as ancilla detectors performing joint Bell measurements that herald the end-to-end entanglement. By forbidding direct pair sources on the \u201cwrong\u201d edges (removed_connections), we encode the SSH alternating coupling:\n\u2022 Intracell: sources connect (0\u21941) and (2\u21943).  \n\u2022 Intercell: source connects (1\u21942).  \n\u2022 Forbidden: no sources on (0\u21942), (0\u21943), or (1\u21943).\n\nThis network:\n\u2022 Realizes an SSH chain in abstract mode-connectivity.  \n\u2022 Implements multi-node entanglement swapping \u2192 teleportation.  \n\u2022 Tests the topological robustness of the teleportation channel (quantum metric of boundary vs bulk couplings).  \n\u2022 Is fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: uses only pair sources, linear optics, ancilla detectors, and post-selection.   \n\nProposed Pytheus config:\n\n{'description': 'Topologically-protected teleportation on a four-site SSH chain via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'SSH_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 30,\n 'ftol': 1e-06,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 10,\n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n 'thresholds': [0.2,0.1],\n 'single_emitters': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n 'unicolor': True,\n 'number_resolving': True,\n 'anc_detectors': [1,2]\n}"

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list. We simulate a four-site SSH chain via a linear-optical entanglement-swapping network. \u2028By constraining which pair sources can emit to which modes, we enforce the alternating \u201cintracell\u201d (0\u20131, 2\u20133) and \u201cintercell\u201d (1\u20132) couplings of the SSH model. Bell measurements at modes 1 and 2 then teleport (swap) entanglement from the left boundary (mode 0) to the right boundary (mode 3). Heralding on the two ancilla detector clicks implements a teleportation channel\u2014effectively a Bell state\u2014between modes 0 and 3. Varying the connectivity or ancilla patterns will let one probe the topological protection of this teleportation.\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to create a maximally entangled state |\u03a6+> = |00>+|11> (without normalization) between end modes 0 and 3, using only probabilistic photon-pair sources and linear optics. No single emitter sends to more than two nodes. Two interior nodes (1 and 2) serve as ancilla detectors performing joint Bell measurements that herald the end-to-end entanglement. By forbidding direct pair sources on the \u201cwrong\u201d edges (removed_connections), we encode the SSH alternating coupling:\n\u2022 Intracell: sources connect (0\u21941) and (2\u21943).  \n\u2022 Intercell: source connects (1\u21942).  \n\u2022 Forbidden: no sources on (0\u21942), (0\u21943), or (1\u21943).\n\nThis network:\n\u2022 Realizes an SSH chain in abstract mode-connectivity.  \n\u2022 Implements multi-node entanglement swapping \u2192 teleportation.  \n\u2022 Tests the topological robustness of the teleportation channel (quantum metric of boundary vs bulk couplings).  \n\u2022 Is fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: uses only pair sources, linear optics, ancilla detectors, and post-selection.   \n\nProposed Pytheus config:\n\n{'description': 'Topologically-protected teleportation on a four-site SSH chain via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'SSH_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 30,\n 'ftol': 1e-06,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 10,\n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n 'thresholds': [0.2,0.1],\n 'single_emitters': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n 'unicolor': True,\n 'number_resolving': True,\n 'anc_detectors': [1,2]\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The core mechanism here is simply entanglement swapping across three Bell pairs (sources on 0\u20131, 1\u20132, 2\u20133) with Bell\u2010measurements on the middle nodes to teleport entanglement to the ends. That is essentially the same primitive as \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d in the known list. Labelling the link pattern as an \u201cSSH chain\u201d does not introduce a new quantum-optical target or nontrivial topological Hamiltonian dynamics\u2014there is no genuine protection or bulk\u2010edge gap being simulated, only a fixed connectivity graph and post\u2010selected teleportation fidelity measurement. As stated, this is a straightforward rephrasing of three\u2010pair entanglement swapping and does not reach the bar for a genuinely novel, publishable PRL proposal. Action: reject  \nAction Input: The proposal reduces to Bell\u2010swap teleportation over three linked photon\u2010pair sources\u2014equivalent to the \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d experiment on your exclusion list. Simply calling the graph \u201cSSH\u201d without engineering a true topological Hamiltonian, probing a gap, or demonstrating genuine robustness beyond ordinary entanglement\u2010swap fidelity does not yield a new quantum\u2010optical target. To improve, you would need to embed actual topological band\u2010structure physics (e.g. synthetic gauge fields, nontrivial winding measurements, higher\u2010dimensional topology, non\u2010Hermitian SSH physics, or measurement\u2010induced topological order) that cannot be reduced to standard multi\u2010pair entanglement swapping."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Alternate \u201cstrong\u201d (intracell) and \u201cweak\u201d (intercell) couplings by specifying only certain pair-source connections. Perform Bell measurements at the two interior nodes (ancilla detectors) to herald a Bell pair between the two end modes, and study how the teleportation fidelity reflects the SSH topological invariant (edge versus bulk coupling patterns).\n    2. \u201cQuantum metric mapping via entanglement swapping\u201d \u2013 build a small SSH chain where one tunes a parameter \u03b8 that continuously interpolates between trivial and topological phases (by reweighting interferometer reflectivities). Use pairs of entangled photons as probes, swap entanglement along various length scales, and extract the Fubini-Study metric in \u03b8 space by measuring output-state overlap variations via Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel-type measurements. The target becomes a network that implements the swap-and-overlap protocol.\n    3. \u201cMulti-path SSH routing of entanglement\u201d \u2013 generalize entanglement swapping to a two-dimensional SSH lattice of four modes arranged in two dimers. Use beam-splitter couplings (with removed_connections to enforce SSH connectivity) and ancilla detectors to route entanglement from one corner to the opposite. Then measure the quantum metric of the routing channel by comparing different routing paths.\n\n  Step 2: Check novelty & Pytheus obstacles.\n    1. Novel: no prior entanglement-swapping experiment has encoded SSH topology to protect/characterize teleportation. Feasible: only pair sources + linear optics + ancilla detectors, no hyper-entanglement or feedback.\n    2. Interesting but Pytheus cannot natively parameter-tune continuous reflectivities or compute metric overlaps.\n    3. Too complex: multi-path SSH lattice might exceed Pytheus\u2019s search space.\n\n  Step 3: Pick idea 1 as most promising.\n\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it directly fuses the SSH topological-chain concept with multi-node entanglement-swapping to realize a \u201ctopologically protected\u201d teleportation channel, never before addressed in linear-optical networks.\n\n  Step 5: This idea is feasible in the pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because:\n    \u2022 It\u2019s a pure quantum network (entanglement swapping \u2192 teleportation).\n    \u2022 It uses only probabilistic photon-pair sources, linear optics, and post\u2010selection.\n    \u2022 No dynamic feedback or cavities are required.\n    \u2022 The target is a Bell state between the two end modes, heralded by ancilla detectors at the interior nodes.\n    \u2022 Connectivity is enforced via removed_connections, encoding the alternating SSH pattern.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for the Expert. We simulate a four-site SSH chain via a linear-optical entanglement-swapping network. \u2028By constraining which pair sources can emit to which modes, we enforce the alternating \u201cintracell\u201d (0\u20131, 2\u20133) and \u201cintercell\u201d (1\u20132) couplings of the SSH model. Bell measurements at modes 1 and 2 then teleport (swap) entanglement from the left boundary (mode 0) to the right boundary (mode 3). Heralding on the two ancilla detector clicks implements a teleportation channel\u2014effectively a Bell state\u2014between modes 0 and 3. Varying the connectivity or ancilla patterns will let one probe the topological protection of this teleportation.\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to create a maximally entangled state |\u03a6+> = |00>+|11> (without normalization) between end modes 0 and 3, using only probabilistic photon-pair sources and linear optics. No single emitter sends to more than two nodes. Two interior nodes (1 and 2) serve as ancilla detectors performing joint Bell measurements that herald the end-to-end entanglement. By forbidding direct pair sources on the \u201cwrong\u201d edges (removed_connections), we encode the SSH alternating coupling:\n\u2022 Intracell: sources connect (0\u21941) and (2\u21943).  \n\u2022 Intercell: source connects (1\u21942).  \n\u2022 Forbidden: no sources on (0\u21942), (0\u21943), or (1\u21943).\n\nThis network:\n\u2022 Realizes an SSH chain in abstract mode-connectivity.  \n\u2022 Implements multi-node entanglement swapping \u2192 teleportation.  \n\u2022 Tests the topological robustness of the teleportation channel (quantum metric of boundary vs bulk couplings).  \n\u2022 Is fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: uses only pair sources, linear optics, ancilla detectors, and post-selection.   \n\nProposed Pytheus config:\n\n{'description': 'Topologically-protected teleportation on a four-site SSH chain via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'SSH_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 30,\n 'ftol': 1e-06,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 10,\n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n 'thresholds': [0.2,0.1],\n 'single_emitters': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n 'unicolor': True,\n 'number_resolving': True,\n 'anc_detectors': [1,2]\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The proposal reduces to Bell\u2010swap teleportation over three linked photon\u2010pair sources\u2014equivalent to the \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d experiment on your exclusion list. Simply calling the graph \u201cSSH\u201d without engineering a true topological Hamiltonian, probing a gap, or demonstrating genuine robustness beyond ordinary entanglement\u2010swap fidelity does not yield a new quantum\u2010optical target.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to fuse \u201cquantum metric\u201d and \u201cSSH chain\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum network:\n    1. A static four\u2010site SSH chain realized with three probabilistic pair sources (intracell/intercell), where one teleports an unknown qubit from one end to the other via entanglement swapping. By varying the relative source amplitudes \u03b1 (intracell) and \u03b2 (intercell), the teleportation fidelity F(\u03b1,\u03b2) encodes the Fubini\u2013Study metric g in the (\u03b1,\u03b2)\u2010parameter space of the two\u2010band SSH model.\n    2. A four\u2010photon Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel\u2013style measurement network that directly interferes two adjacent Bloch\u2010states |\u03c8(k)\u3009 and |\u03c8(k+\u03b4k)\u3009 of the SSH chain\u2014each encoded by a pair source with phase\u2010shifted intracell coupling\u2014and reads out the overlap 1\u2013|\u3008\u03c8(k)|\u03c8(k+\u03b4k)\u3009|\u00b2\u221dg(k)\u03b4k\u00b2 via post\u2010selected coincidences.\n    3. An N\u2010cell entanglement\u2010swapping chain that distinguishes trivial vs. topological SSH phases by the minimal ancilla count required for end\u2010to\u2010end teleportation. The ancilla\u2010count as a function of unit\u2010cell count N serves as a \u201cresource\u2010metric\u201d that jumps at the topological transition, revealing a winding\u2010number signature.\n\n  Step 2: Quick novelty & feasibility check:\n    1. Novel: directly ties teleportation fidelity to the SSH band quantum metric. Feasible: uses only static pair sources, linear optics, adjustable source amplitudes, and ancilla Bell measurements\u2014no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities.\n    2. Interesting, but designing a four\u2010photon HOM network to read out infinitesimal overlaps is practically a state\u2010generation/measurement task that Pytheus may struggle to optimize as a \u201ctarget quantum.\u201d\n    3. Resource\u2010count metric is clever but uses ancilla count as a proxy for \u201cmetric,\u201d which is more abstract and less direct than measuring the true Fubini\u2013Study metric.\n\n  Step 3: The most promising is (1): \u201cSSH\u2010parameter\u2010space teleportation with fidelity\u2010based quantum metric.\u201d  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no prior linear\u2010optical network has used entanglement swapping over an SSH\u2010connectivity graph to directly map out the Fubini\u2013Study metric of a two\u2010band topological model via teleportation fidelity.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because:\n    \u2022 The network is purely a quantum communication/entanglement\u2010swapping protocol\u2014no forbidden state\u2010generation.  \n    \u2022 Only probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, adjustable source\u2010amplitude weights (intracell vs. intercell), static beam\u2010splitters, and post\u2010selected ancilla detectors are required.  \n    \u2022 Pytheus can handle \u201camplitudes\u201d in the config to encode \u03b1 and \u03b2.  \n    \u2022 No dynamic feedback, no cavities, no hybrid\u2010entanglement, and no hyper\u2010entanglement.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for the Expert:\n\nTitle: \u201cTeleportation\u2010Fidelity Quantum\u2010Metric Tomography on an SSH Entanglement\u2010Swapping Chain\u201d\n\nGoal:\nDesign a linear\u2010optical network that (a) realizes a three\u2010node \u201cSSH\u201d graph via three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources with two different amplitudes\u2014\u03b1 for intracell links and \u03b2 for the single intercell link\u2014and (b) uses Bell\u2010state measurements (ancilla detectors) at the two interior nodes to teleport an unknown qubit from mode 0 to mode 3. By scanning the ratio \u03b2/\u03b1 and recording the heralded teleportation fidelity F(\u03b2/\u03b1), one directly measures the Fubini\u2013Study quantum metric g(\u03b2/\u03b1) = 4[1 \u2013 \u221aF]/(d(\u03b2/\u03b1))\u00b2 of the underlying two\u2010band SSH parameter manifold.\n\nVisualization:\n   Pair\u2010source S\u2081 (\u03b1)            S\u2082 (\u03b2)            S\u2083 (\u03b1)  \n   modes: 0\u21941 \u2014\u2014\u2014 modes: 1\u21942 \u2014\u2014\u2014 modes: 2\u21943  \n          \u2193 Bell M\u2081              \u2193 Bell M\u2082  \n       detectors 1 & 2 herald the swap  \n   Input qubit encoded on mode 0; teleported to mode 3.\n\nKey features:\n\u2022 Three probabilistic pair sources with tunable relative amplitudes (\u03b1,\u03b2).  \n\u2022 Two ancilla Bell measurements at interior nodes 1 and 2 (post\u2010selected clicks herald teleportation).  \n\u2022 Output: mode 3 carries the teleported qubit; fidelity F(\u03b2/\u03b1) is measured versus \u03b2/\u03b1.  \n\u2022 The curvature of F(\u03b2/\u03b1) as a function of \u03b2/\u03b1 directly yields the quantum metric g of the SSH model\u2019s band eigenstates.  \n\u2022 Full compliance with Pytheus: only pair sources, linear optics, amplitude weights, and ancilla detectors\u2014no dynamic feedback or forbidden elements.\n\nSuggested Pytheus\u2010style config sketch (to be refined by the Expert):\n{\n  'description': 'SSH\u2010chain teleportation for quantum\u2010metric tomography',\n  'foldername': 'SSH_qmetric_tel',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 20,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],   # heralded Bell pair between 0 & 3\n  'single_emitters': [],\n  'amplitudes': [\u03b1, \u03b2, \u03b1],         # source amplitudes for S\u2081, S\u2082, S\u2083\n  'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n  'anc_detectors': [1,2],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNext steps:\nThe Expert can hand\u2010off this abstract target to Pytheus, scan the \u03b2/\u03b1 parameter externally, and produce a teleportation\u2010fidelity curve whose second derivative maps out the quantum metric of the SSH manifold\u2014yielding both a novel linear\u2010optical quantum network and a direct experimental protocol for quantum\u2010metric tomography in a topological model."

Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list. There is no nontrivial topological or dynamical effect beyond standard entanglement swapping, nor any novel measurement of a truly inaccessible observable. For instance, engineer a tunable synthetic band structure in the optical modes (e.g. implement dynamic phase gradients, non\u2013Hermitian loss/gain to create exceptional points, or higher\u2010dimensional SSH lattices), and then directly measure topologically protected invariants (like winding numbers) or Berry curvature through an interferometric scheme that cannot be reduced to post\u2010selected Bell\u2010swap fidelities."

{
    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Field test of mode-pairing quantum key distribution\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Efficient algorithms for simulating percolation in photonic fusion\n  networks\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Accelerating the training of single-layer binary neural networks using\n  the HHL quantum algorithm\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. THE FEEDBACK IS INCREDIBLE IMPORTANT !!! FOR SURE LOOK AT THEM AND UNDERSTAND THE CORE IDEA OF THEM!! YOU HAVE FAILED SO OFTEN BEFORE, FREAKING TAKE IT SERIOUS!\n\nSTART OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n<existing_feedback>\nEND OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n\nThis feedback is extremely important and very valuable information. It should be taken very seriously. Take it into account when coming up with your own idea. TAKE IT SERIOUS, THE FEEDBACK IS VERY IMPORTANT!!!!! BEFORE CREATING AN IDEA, THINK ABOUT WHETHER MY PREVIOUS FEEDBACK WOULD ALLOW IT!!!\n\nBe constructively critical of your own idea and check if it is novel. Refine it and aim for producing a truly novel idea.\n\nHere are the targets that pytheus has already designed quantum optics experiments for.  A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"quantum metric\" and \"ssh chain\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Alternate \u201cstrong\u201d (intracell) and \u201cweak\u201d (intercell) couplings by specifying only certain pair-source connections. Perform Bell measurements at the two interior nodes (ancilla detectors) to herald a Bell pair between the two end modes, and study how the teleportation fidelity reflects the SSH topological invariant (edge versus bulk coupling patterns).\n    2. \u201cQuantum metric mapping via entanglement swapping\u201d \u2013 build a small SSH chain where one tunes a parameter \u03b8 that continuously interpolates between trivial and topological phases (by reweighting interferometer reflectivities). Use pairs of entangled photons as probes, swap entanglement along various length scales, and extract the Fubini-Study metric in \u03b8 space by measuring output-state overlap variations via Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel-type measurements. The target becomes a network that implements the swap-and-overlap protocol.\n    3. \u201cMulti-path SSH routing of entanglement\u201d \u2013 generalize entanglement swapping to a two-dimensional SSH lattice of four modes arranged in two dimers. Use beam-splitter couplings (with removed_connections to enforce SSH connectivity) and ancilla detectors to route entanglement from one corner to the opposite. Then measure the quantum metric of the routing channel by comparing different routing paths.\n\n  Step 2: Check novelty & Pytheus obstacles.\n    1. We simulate a four-site SSH chain via a linear-optical entanglement-swapping network. \u2028By constraining which pair sources can emit to which modes, we enforce the alternating \u201cintracell\u201d (0\u20131, 2\u20133) and \u201cintercell\u201d (1\u20132) couplings of the SSH model. Bell measurements at modes 1 and 2 then teleport (swap) entanglement from the left boundary (mode 0) to the right boundary (mode 3). Heralding on the two ancilla detector clicks implements a teleportation channel\u2014effectively a Bell state\u2014between modes 0 and 3. Varying the connectivity or ancilla patterns will let one probe the topological protection of this teleportation.\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to create a maximally entangled state |\u03a6+> = |00>+|11> (without normalization) between end modes 0 and 3, using only probabilistic photon-pair sources and linear optics. No single emitter sends to more than two nodes. Two interior nodes (1 and 2) serve as ancilla detectors performing joint Bell measurements that herald the end-to-end entanglement. By forbidding direct pair sources on the \u201cwrong\u201d edges (removed_connections), we encode the SSH alternating coupling:\n\u2022 Intracell: sources connect (0\u21941) and (2\u21943).  \n\u2022 Intercell: source connects (1\u21942).  \n\u2022 Forbidden: no sources on (0\u21942), (0\u21943), or (1\u21943).\n\nThis network:\n\u2022 Realizes an SSH chain in abstract mode-connectivity.  \n\u2022 Implements multi-node entanglement swapping \u2192 teleportation.  \n\u2022 Tests the topological robustness of the teleportation channel (quantum metric of boundary vs bulk couplings).  \n\u2022 Is fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: uses only pair sources, linear optics, ancilla detectors, and post-selection.   \n\nProposed Pytheus config:\n\n{'description': 'Topologically-protected teleportation on a four-site SSH chain via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'SSH_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 30,\n 'ftol': 1e-06,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 10,\n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n 'thresholds': [0.2,0.1],\n 'single_emitters': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n 'unicolor': True,\n 'number_resolving': True,\n 'anc_detectors': [1,2]\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The proposal reduces to Bell\u2010swap teleportation over three linked photon\u2010pair sources\u2014equivalent to the \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d experiment on your exclusion list. A static four\u2010site SSH chain realized with three probabilistic pair sources (intracell/intercell), where one teleports an unknown qubit from one end to the other via entanglement swapping. By varying the relative source amplitudes \u03b1 (intracell) and \u03b2 (intercell), the teleportation fidelity F(\u03b1,\u03b2) encodes the Fubini\u2013Study metric g in the (\u03b1,\u03b2)\u2010parameter space of the two\u2010band SSH model.\n    2. A four\u2010photon Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel\u2013style measurement network that directly interferes two adjacent Bloch\u2010states |\u03c8(k)\u3009 and |\u03c8(k+\u03b4k)\u3009 of the SSH chain\u2014each encoded by a pair source with phase\u2010shifted intracell coupling\u2014and reads out the overlap 1\u2013|\u3008\u03c8(k)|\u03c8(k+\u03b4k)\u3009|\u00b2\u221dg(k)\u03b4k\u00b2 via post\u2010selected coincidences.\n    3. An N\u2010cell entanglement\u2010swapping chain that distinguishes trivial vs. topological SSH phases by the minimal ancilla count required for end\u2010to\u2010end teleportation. The ancilla\u2010count as a function of unit\u2010cell count N serves as a \u201cresource\u2010metric\u201d that jumps at the topological transition, revealing a winding\u2010number signature.\n\n  Step 2: Quick novelty & feasibility check:\n    1. Feasible: uses only static pair sources, linear optics, adjustable source amplitudes, and ancilla Bell measurements\u2014no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities.\n    2. Interesting, but designing a four\u2010photon HOM network to read out infinitesimal overlaps is practically a state\u2010generation/measurement task that Pytheus may struggle to optimize as a \u201ctarget quantum.\u201d\n    3. Resource\u2010count metric is clever but uses ancilla count as a proxy for \u201cmetric,\u201d which is more abstract and less direct than measuring the true Fubini\u2013Study metric.\n\n  Step 3: The most promising is (1): \u201cSSH\u2010parameter\u2010space teleportation with fidelity\u2010based quantum metric.\u201d  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no prior linear\u2010optical network has used entanglement swapping over an SSH\u2010connectivity graph to directly map out the Fubini\u2013Study metric of a two\u2010band topological model via teleportation fidelity.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because:\n    \u2022 The network is purely a quantum communication/entanglement\u2010swapping protocol\u2014no forbidden state\u2010generation.  \n    \u2022 Only probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, adjustable source\u2010amplitude weights (intracell vs. intercell), static beam\u2010splitters, and post\u2010selected ancilla detectors are required.  \n    \u2022 Pytheus can handle \u201camplitudes\u201d in the config to encode \u03b1 and \u03b2.  \n    \u2022 No dynamic feedback, no cavities, no hybrid\u2010entanglement, and no hyper\u2010entanglement.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for the Expert:\n\nTitle: \u201cTeleportation\u2010Fidelity Quantum\u2010Metric Tomography on an SSH Entanglement\u2010Swapping Chain\u201d\n\nGoal:\nDesign a linear\u2010optical network that (a) realizes a three\u2010node \u201cSSH\u201d graph via three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources with two different amplitudes\u2014\u03b1 for intracell links and \u03b2 for the single intercell link\u2014and (b) uses Bell\u2010state measurements (ancilla detectors) at the two interior nodes to teleport an unknown qubit from mode 0 to mode 3. By scanning the ratio \u03b2/\u03b1 and recording the heralded teleportation fidelity F(\u03b2/\u03b1), one directly measures the Fubini\u2013Study quantum metric g(\u03b2/\u03b1) = 4[1 \u2013 \u221aF]/(d(\u03b2/\u03b1))\u00b2 of the underlying two\u2010band SSH parameter manifold.\n\nVisualization:\n   Pair\u2010source S\u2081 (\u03b1)            S\u2082 (\u03b2)            S\u2083 (\u03b1)  \n   modes: 0\u21941 \u2014\u2014\u2014 modes: 1\u21942 \u2014\u2014\u2014 modes: 2\u21943  \n          \u2193 Bell M\u2081              \u2193 Bell M\u2082  \n       detectors 1 & 2 herald the swap  \n   Input qubit encoded on mode 0; teleported to mode 3.\n\nKey features:\n\u2022 Three probabilistic pair sources with tunable relative amplitudes (\u03b1,\u03b2).  \n\u2022 Two ancilla Bell measurements at interior nodes 1 and 2 (post\u2010selected clicks herald teleportation).  \n\u2022 Output: mode 3 carries the teleported qubit; fidelity F(\u03b2/\u03b1) is measured versus \u03b2/\u03b1.  \n\u2022 The curvature of F(\u03b2/\u03b1) as a function of \u03b2/\u03b1 directly yields the quantum metric g of the SSH model\u2019s band eigenstates.  \n\u2022 Full compliance with Pytheus: only pair sources, linear optics, amplitude weights, and ancilla detectors\u2014no dynamic feedback or forbidden elements.\n\nSuggested Pytheus\u2010style config sketch (to be refined by the Expert):\n{\n  'description': 'SSH\u2010chain teleportation for quantum\u2010metric tomography',\n  'foldername': 'SSH_qmetric_tel',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 20,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],   # heralded Bell pair between 0 & 3\n  'single_emitters': [],\n  'amplitudes': [\u03b1, \u03b2, \u03b1],         # source amplitudes for S\u2081, S\u2082, S\u2083\n  'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n  'anc_detectors': [1,2],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNext steps:\nThe Expert can hand\u2010off this abstract target to Pytheus, scan the \u03b2/\u03b1 parameter externally, and produce a teleportation\u2010fidelity curve whose second derivative maps out the quantum metric of the SSH manifold\u2014yielding both a novel linear\u2010optical quantum network and a direct experimental protocol for quantum\u2010metric tomography in a topological model.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To improve, you would need to go beyond simple fidelity scanning on a fixed three\u2010pair graph. For instance, engineer a tunable synthetic band structure in the optical modes (e.g. implement dynamic phase gradients, non\u2013Hermitian loss/gain to create exceptional points, or higher\u2010dimensional SSH lattices), and then directly measure topologically protected invariants (like winding numbers) or Berry curvature through an interferometric scheme that cannot be reduced to post\u2010selected Bell\u2010swap fidelities.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm 3 ways to fuse \"quantum metric\" and \"SSH chain\" in a Pytheus-compatible quantum network (no state generation, only entanglement-swapping/teleportation):\n  1. Teleportation-fidelity mapping of the SSH quantum metric: a three-bond chain with adjustable intracell (\u03b1) and intercell (\u03b2) source amplitudes; two Bell measurements in the interior teleport a qubit end\u2192end. Scanning \u03b2/\u03b1 yields fidelity F(\u03b2/\u03b1), whose curvature gives the Fubini\u2013Study metric of the SSH band.\n  2. Measurement-induced detection of SSH edge modes: build a four-site SSH chain (\u03b1\u2013\u03b2\u2013\u03b1 bonds), perform only two interior Bell measurements and postselect on end-to-end entanglement. In the topological regime (\u03b2>\u03b1) ends become entangled; in the trivial regime (\u03b2<\u03b1) cancellation prevents teleportation. The sudden appearance of heralded entanglement is a measurement-based winding-number indicator.\n  3. Resource-count phase detector: vary the number of ancilla Bell measurements required to teleport a qubit across an N-site alternating chain; the minimal ancilla count jumps at the SSH topological transition.  \nStep 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n  1. Fidelity-mapping (idea 1) is really just scanning fidelity\u2014too close to prior feedback.  \n  2. Edge-mode entanglement (idea 2) is purely a network, not state generation, and uses the existence or absence of teleportation as a topological order parameter. It goes beyond mere fidelity scanning and encodes a winding-number signature via a binary entanglement/no-entanglement output.  \n  3. Resource-count (idea 3) is abstract and less direct, and might be hard to phrase as one Pytheus target.  \nStep 3: Pick idea 2 as most promising.\nStep 4: Novelty: No prior linear-optical entanglement-swapping experiment has used a two-measurement teleportation protocol whose success vanishes in the trivial SSH regime and appears only above the topological threshold. This binary \u201cteleportation on/off\u201d constitutes a measurement-induced topological invariant test, not just fidelity or state generation.  \nStep 5: Feasibility:  \n  \u2022 Pure network protocol: three probabilistic photon-pair sources, static beam-splitters with amplitude weights \u03b1,\u03b2, two ancilla Bell detectors, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2022 Pytheus can optimize such a network with \u201camplitudes\u201d for sources and \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to enforce the SSH graph, plus \u201canc_detectors\u201d to herald the swap.  \n  \u2022 The Expert can externally choose \u03b1<\u03b2 or \u03b1>\u03b2 and observe heralded coincidence rates \u2192 zero vs nonzero.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for the Expert:\n\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Detection of SSH Edge Modes via Binary Teleportation\n\nGoal:\nRealize a four-mode SSH chain (modes 0\u20131\u20132\u20133) in an entanglement-swapping network. Three probabilistic photon-pair sources provide bonds 0\u20131 (amplitude \u03b1), 1\u20132 (\u03b2), and 2\u20133 (\u03b1). Two interior nodes (1 and 2) perform Bell-state measurements (ancilla detectors). We herald a Bell pair between the end modes 0 and 3. The key is that in the trivial regime (\u03b2<\u03b1) destructive interference cancels all paths \u2192 zero heralding rate (no end-to-end teleportation), whereas in the topological regime (\u03b2>\u03b1) a robust nonzero heralding rate appears. The abrupt \u201coff\u2192on\u201d behaviour as \u03b2 crosses \u03b1 is a measurement-induced winding-number signature of the SSH model.\n\nVisualization:\n   Source S\u2081(\u03b1)       S\u2082(\u03b2)        S\u2083(\u03b1)\n   mode 0 \u27f7 mode 1 \u2014 mode 1 \u27f7 mode 2 \u2014 mode 2 \u27f7 mode 3\n         \u2198 Bell M\u2081      \u2198 Bell M\u2082\n           det 1           det 2\n   Heralded clicks at det 1&2 \u21d2 entangled output between modes 0 & 3\n\nKey Features:\n\u2022 Only probabilistic pair sources + static linear optics.  \n\u2022 Source amplitudes [\u03b1,\u03b2,\u03b1] realize the SSH intracell/intercell pattern.  \n\u2022 removed_connections:[[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]] enforce no unwanted bonds.  \n\u2022 anc_detectors: [1,2] perform Bell measurements.  \n\u2022 target_quantum:['00','11'] between output modes [0,3].  \n\u2022 In Pytheus: you ask for a setup that gives a maximally entangled Bell pair at modes 0&3 conditioned on clicks at ancilla detectors.  \n\u2022 The Expert then varies \u03b2/\u03b1 externally to observe the heralding probability jump at the topological transition.\n\nSuggested Pytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'SSH edge\u2010mode detector via binary teleportation',\n  'foldername': 'SSH_edge_teleport',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 20,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'amplitudes': ['\u03b1','\u03b2','\u03b1'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n  'anc_detectors': [1,2],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNext Steps:\n1. Hand to Pytheus to find concrete beam-splitter parameters for given \u03b1,\u03b2.  \n2. Externally sweep \u03b2/\u03b1 across 1; record herald rate.  \n3. The \u201coff\u2192on\u201d heralded end-to-end entanglement directly signals the SSH winding number\u2014an experimentally accessible, measurement-induced topological invariant without state generation or dynamic control."

Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list. We simulate a four-site SSH chain via a linear-optical entanglement-swapping network. \u2028By constraining which pair sources can emit to which modes, we enforce the alternating \u201cintracell\u201d (0\u20131, 2\u20133) and \u201cintercell\u201d (1\u20132) couplings of the SSH model. Bell measurements at modes 1 and 2 then teleport (swap) entanglement from the left boundary (mode 0) to the right boundary (mode 3). Heralding on the two ancilla detector clicks implements a teleportation channel\u2014effectively a Bell state\u2014between modes 0 and 3. Varying the connectivity or ancilla patterns will let one probe the topological protection of this teleportation.\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to create a maximally entangled state |\u03a6+> = |00>+|11> (without normalization) between end modes 0 and 3, using only probabilistic photon-pair sources and linear optics. No single emitter sends to more than two nodes. Two interior nodes (1 and 2) serve as ancilla detectors performing joint Bell measurements that herald the end-to-end entanglement.     "output": "Thought: While mapping the abrupt on/off heralding rate to an \u201cedge\u2010mode\u201d signature is a clever reinterpretation, the underlying network is still just three Bell\u2010pair sources with post\u2010selected entanglement swapping\u2014essentially the same as the \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d setup. The zero heralding in the trivial regime merely reflects the absence of a source (\u03b2\u21920), not a genuine topological phase with a protected bulk gap. There is no nontrivial Hamiltonian dynamics, no Berry phase measurement, and no new quantum-optical target beyond standard multi-pair swapping.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is too close to the known three\u2010pair entanglement\u2010swapping experiment. To be novel, you must embed true topological physics\u2014e.g. implement a synthetic Hamiltonian with nonzero winding number, measure Berry curvature or winding via interferometry, or create robustness against disorder via genuine edge states\u2014rather than rely on simple connectivity on/off in a static swapping network."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. A static four\u2010site SSH chain realized with three probabilistic pair sources (intracell/intercell), where one teleports an unknown qubit from one end to the other via entanglement swapping. By varying the relative source amplitudes \u03b1 (intracell) and \u03b2 (intercell), the teleportation fidelity F(\u03b1,\u03b2) encodes the Fubini\u2013Study metric g in the (\u03b1,\u03b2)\u2010parameter space of the two\u2010band SSH model.\n    2. A four\u2010photon Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel\u2013style measurement network that directly interferes two adjacent Bloch\u2010states |\u03c8(k)\u3009 and |\u03c8(k+\u03b4k)\u3009 of the SSH chain\u2014each encoded by a pair source with phase\u2010shifted intracell coupling\u2014and reads out the overlap 1\u2013|\u3008\u03c8(k)|\u03c8(k+\u03b4k)\u3009|\u00b2\u221dg(k)\u03b4k\u00b2 via post\u2010selected coincidences.\n    3. An N\u2010cell entanglement\u2010swapping chain that distinguishes trivial vs. topological SSH phases by the minimal ancilla count required for end\u2010to\u2010end teleportation. The ancilla\u2010count as a function of unit\u2010cell count N serves as a \u201cresource\u2010metric\u201d that jumps at the topological transition, revealing a winding\u2010number signature.\n\n  Step 2: Quick novelty & feasibility check:\n    1. Novel: directly ties teleportation fidelity to the SSH band quantum metric. Feasible: uses only static pair sources, linear optics, adjustable source amplitudes, and ancilla Bell measurements\u2014no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities.\n    2. Interesting, but designing a four\u2010photon HOM network to read out infinitesimal overlaps is practically a state\u2010generation/measurement task that Pytheus may struggle to optimize as a \u201ctarget quantum.\u201d\n    3. Resource\u2010count metric is clever but uses ancilla count as a proxy for \u201cmetric,\u201d which is more abstract and less direct than measuring the true Fubini\u2013Study metric.\n\n  Step 3: The most promising is (1): \u201cSSH\u2010parameter\u2010space teleportation with fidelity\u2010based quantum metric.\u201d  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no prior linear\u2010optical network has used entanglement swapping over an SSH\u2010connectivity graph to directly map out the Fubini\u2013Study metric of a two\u2010band topological model via teleportation fidelity.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because:\n    \u2022 The network is purely a quantum communication/entanglement\u2010swapping protocol\u2014no forbidden state\u2010generation.  \n    \u2022 Only probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, adjustable source\u2010amplitude weights (intracell vs. intercell), static beam\u2010splitters, and post\u2010selected ancilla detectors are required.  \n    \u2022 Pytheus can handle \u201camplitudes\u201d in the config to encode \u03b1 and \u03b2.  \n    \u2022 No dynamic feedback, no cavities, no hybrid\u2010entanglement, and no hyper\u2010entanglement.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for the Expert:\n\nTitle: \u201cTeleportation\u2010Fidelity Quantum\u2010Metric Tomography on an SSH Entanglement\u2010Swapping Chain\u201d\n\nGoal:\nDesign a linear\u2010optical network that (a) realizes a three\u2010node \u201cSSH\u201d graph via three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources with two different amplitudes\u2014\u03b1 for intracell links and \u03b2 for the single intercell link\u2014and (b) uses Bell\u2010state measurements (ancilla detectors) at the two interior nodes to teleport an unknown qubit from mode 0 to mode 3. By scanning the ratio \u03b2/\u03b1 and recording the heralded teleportation fidelity F(\u03b2/\u03b1), one directly measures the Fubini\u2013Study quantum metric g(\u03b2/\u03b1) = 4[1 \u2013 \u221aF]/(d(\u03b2/\u03b1))\u00b2 of the underlying two\u2010band SSH parameter manifold.\n\nVisualization:\n   Pair\u2010source S\u2081 (\u03b1)            S\u2082 (\u03b2)            S\u2083 (\u03b1)  \n   modes: 0\u21941 \u2014\u2014\u2014 modes: 1\u21942 \u2014\u2014\u2014 modes: 2\u21943  \n          \u2193 Bell M\u2081              \u2193 Bell M\u2082  \n       detectors 1 & 2 herald the swap  \n   Input qubit encoded on mode 0; fidelity F(\u03b2/\u03b1) is measured versus \u03b2/\u03b1.  \n\u2022 The curvature of F(\u03b2/\u03b1) as a function of \u03b2/\u03b1 directly yields the quantum metric g of the SSH model\u2019s band eigenstates.  \n\u2022 Full compliance with Pytheus: only pair sources, linear optics, amplitude weights, and ancilla detectors\u2014no dynamic feedback or forbidden elements.\n\nSuggested Pytheus\u2010style config sketch (to be refined by the Expert):\n{\n  'description': 'SSH\u2010chain teleportation for quantum\u2010metric tomography',\n  'foldername': 'SSH_qmetric_tel',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 20,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],   # heralded Bell pair between 0 & 3\n  'single_emitters': [],\n  'amplitudes': [\u03b1, \u03b2, \u03b1],         # source amplitudes for S\u2081, S\u2082, S\u2083\n  'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n  'anc_detectors': [1,2],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNext steps:\nThe Expert can hand\u2010off this abstract target to Pytheus, scan the \u03b2/\u03b1 parameter externally, and produce a teleportation\u2010fidelity curve whose second derivative maps out the quantum metric of the SSH manifold\u2014yielding both a novel linear\u2010optical quantum network and a direct experimental protocol for quantum\u2010metric tomography in a topological model.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To improve, you would need to go beyond simple fidelity scanning on a fixed three\u2010pair graph. Teleportation-fidelity mapping of the SSH quantum metric: a three-bond chain with adjustable intracell (\u03b1) and intercell (\u03b2) source amplitudes; two Bell measurements in the interior teleport a qubit end\u2192end. Scanning \u03b2/\u03b1 yields fidelity F(\u03b2/\u03b1), whose curvature gives the Fubini\u2013Study metric of the SSH band.\n  2. Measurement-induced detection of SSH edge modes: build a four-site SSH chain (\u03b1\u2013\u03b2\u2013\u03b1 bonds), perform only two interior Bell measurements and postselect on end-to-end entanglement. In the topological regime (\u03b2>\u03b1) ends become entangled; in the trivial regime (\u03b2<\u03b1) cancellation prevents teleportation. The sudden appearance of heralded entanglement is a measurement-based winding-number indicator.\n  3. Resource-count phase detector: vary the number of ancilla Bell measurements required to teleport a qubit across an N-site alternating chain; the minimal ancilla count jumps at the SSH topological transition.  \nStep 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n  1. Fidelity-mapping (idea 1) is really just scanning fidelity\u2014too close to prior feedback.  \n  2. Edge-mode entanglement (idea 2) is purely a network, not state generation, and uses the existence or absence of teleportation as a topological order parameter. It goes beyond mere fidelity scanning and encodes a winding-number signature via a binary entanglement/no-entanglement output.  \n  3. This binary \u201cteleportation on/off\u201d constitutes a measurement-induced topological invariant test, not just fidelity or state generation.  \nStep 5: Feasibility:  \n  \u2022 Pure network protocol: three probabilistic photon-pair sources, static beam-splitters with amplitude weights \u03b1,\u03b2, two ancilla Bell detectors, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2022 Pytheus can optimize such a network with \u201camplitudes\u201d for sources and \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to enforce the SSH graph, plus \u201canc_detectors\u201d to herald the swap.  \n  \u2022 The Expert can externally choose \u03b1<\u03b2 or \u03b1>\u03b2 and observe heralded coincidence rates \u2192 zero vs nonzero.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for the Expert:\n\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Detection of SSH Edge Modes via Binary Teleportation\n\nGoal:\nRealize a four-mode SSH chain (modes 0\u20131\u20132\u20133) in an entanglement-swapping network. Three probabilistic photon-pair sources provide bonds 0\u20131 (amplitude \u03b1), 1\u20132 (\u03b2), and 2\u20133 (\u03b1). Two interior nodes (1 and 2) perform Bell-state measurements (ancilla detectors). We herald a Bell pair between the end modes 0 and 3. The key is that in the trivial regime (\u03b2<\u03b1) destructive interference cancels all paths \u2192 zero heralding rate (no end-to-end teleportation), whereas in the topological regime (\u03b2>\u03b1) a robust nonzero heralding rate appears.
