To achieve genuine novelty suitable for PRL, you must go beyond static, post-selected Bell swaps\u2014e.g. implement an actual Floquet drive via time-periodic multiport interferometers or non-Hermitian gain/loss modulation, and directly measure a nontrivial topological invariant (winding number or Berry curvature) through interferometry or spectral analysis rather than coincidence-rate jumps.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposal for the Expert:\n\nTitle:\nQuantum\u2010Metric Tomography of the SSH Band via Entanglement\u2010Swapping Teleportation\n\nGoal:\nDesign a static linear\u2010optical network that realizes a four\u2010mode SSH chain (modes 0\u20131\u20132\u20133) with tunable intracell amplitude \u03b1 and intercell amplitude \u03b2\u2009e^{i\u03b8}. By performing two interior Bell\u2010state measurements (ancilla detectors at modes 1 and 2), an unknown qubit is teleported from mode 0 to mode 3. The heralded teleportation fidelity \nF(\u03b2/\u03b1,\u03b8) = Prob[Bell pair | clicks at ancilla]\ndirectly tracks the Fubini\u2013Study metric of the SSH two\u2010band eigenstates as a function of both parameters. By scanning \u03b2/\u03b1 and \u03b8 externally and recording F, one can reconstruct the metric tensor g_{ij} = Re[\u3008\u2202_i\u03c8|\u2202_j\u03c8\u3009\u2212\u3008\u2202_i\u03c8|\u03c8\u3009\u3008\u03c8|\u2202_j\u03c8\u3009] of the SSH manifold\u2014mapping out local curvature and detecting critical points at \u03b2/\u03b1=1.\n\nVisualization:\n\n   Pair sources:      0 \u27f7 1          1 \u27f7 2          2 \u27f7 3  \n                      S\u2081(\u03b1)           S\u2082(\u03b2\u00b7e^{i\u03b8})    S\u2083(\u03b1)\n                            \u2198Bell M\u2081     \u2198Bell M\u2082\n                             det 1        det 2\n\n  Input qubit on mode 0 \u2192 teleported to mode 3 on ancilla clicks.\n\nKey Features:\n\u2022 Probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources only; three sources with complex amplitudes ['\u03b1','\u03b2\u00b7exp(i*\u03b8)','\u03b1'].  \n\u2022 removed_connections = [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]] enforce the 1D SSH connectivity.  \n\u2022 anc_detectors = [1,2] perform two Bell\u2010swap measurements.  \n\u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] between modes [0,3] conditioned on ancilla clicks.  \n\u2022 By external sweeps of (\u03b2/\u03b1,\u03b8) and measuring F(\u03b2/\u03b1,\u03b8), one obtains the full quantum metric of a topological SSH band\u2014fusing \u201cquantum metric\u201d and \u201cSSH chain\u201d in a pure teleportation network without state\u2010generation or feedback.\n\nSuggested Pytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n\n{\n  'description': 'SSH\u2010chain teleportation for quantum\u2010metric tomography',\n  'foldername': 'SSH_qmetric_tel',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 25,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'imaginary': True,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'amplitudes': ['\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03b8)','\u03b1'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n  'anc_detectors': [1,2],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNext Steps:\n1.     "output": "Thought: This proposal again reduces to a static three-source, two-Bell-swap network\u2014identical in core to the \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d setup on modes 0\u20131\u20132\u20133. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. Teleportation-fidelity mapping of the SSH quantum metric: a three-bond chain with adjustable intracell (\u03b1) and intercell (\u03b2) source amplitudes; two Bell measurements in the interior teleport a qubit end\u2192end. Scanning \u03b2/\u03b1 yields fidelity F(\u03b2/\u03b1), whose curvature gives the Fubini\u2013Study metric of the SSH band.\n  2. Measurement-induced detection of SSH edge modes: build a four-site SSH chain (\u03b1\u2013\u03b2\u2013\u03b1 bonds), perform only two interior Bell measurements and postselect on end-to-end entanglement. In the topological regime (\u03b2>\u03b1) ends become entangled; in the trivial regime (\u03b2<\u03b1) cancellation prevents teleportation. The sudden appearance of heralded entanglement is a measurement-based winding-number indicator.\n  3. Resource-count phase detector: vary the number of ancilla Bell measurements required to teleport a qubit across an N-site alternating chain; the minimal ancilla count jumps at the SSH topological transition.  \nStep 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n  1. Fidelity-mapping (idea 1) is really just scanning fidelity\u2014too close to prior feedback.  \n  2. Edge-mode entanglement (idea 2) is purely a network, not state generation, and uses the existence or absence of teleportation as a topological order parameter. It goes beyond mere fidelity scanning and encodes a winding-number signature via a binary entanglement/no-entanglement output.  \n  3. Resource-count (idea 3) is abstract and less direct, and might be hard to phrase as one Pytheus target.  \nStep 3: Pick idea 2 as most promising.\nStep 4: Novelty: No prior linear-optical entanglement-swapping experiment has used a two-measurement teleportation protocol whose success vanishes in the trivial SSH regime and appears only above the topological threshold. Three probabilistic photon-pair sources provide bonds 0\u20131 (amplitude \u03b1), 1\u20132 (\u03b2), and 2\u20133 (\u03b1). Two interior nodes (1 and 2) perform Bell-state measurements (ancilla detectors). We herald a Bell pair between the end modes 0 and 3. The key is that in the trivial regime (\u03b2<\u03b1) destructive interference cancels all paths \u2192 zero heralding rate (no end-to-end teleportation), whereas in the topological regime (\u03b2>\u03b1) a robust nonzero heralding rate appears. Three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources provide bonds 0\u20131 (\u03b1), 1\u20132 (\u03b2), and 2\u20133 (\u03b1). Two interior modes (1 and 2) perform Bell measurements (ancilla detectors). We prepare an unknown qubit on one end and attempt to teleport it to the other:\n\n\u2022 Forward channel: mode 0\u2192mode 3  \n\u2022 Reverse channel: mode 3\u2192mode 0  \n\nIn the trivial phase (\u03b2<\u03b1) teleportation succeeds only in the reverse direction; in the topological phase (\u03b2>\u03b1) it flips\u2014only the forward channel works. The sharp change of success\u2010rate asymmetry at \u03b2=\u03b1 is a direct network\u2010level signature of the SSH winding number.\n\nVisualization:\n   S\u2081(\u03b1)       S\u2082(\u03b2)       S\u2083(\u03b1)\n  mode 0\u27f7mode 1\u2014mode 1\u27f7mode 2\u2014mode 2\u27f7mode 3\n         \u2198Bell M\u2081     \u2198Bell M\u2082\n         det 1        det 2\nCase A: input qubit at 0 \u21d2 attempt teleport to 3; heralded by clicks at {det 1, det 2}.  \nCase B: input at 3 \u21d2 attempt teleport to 0; same ancilla measurement.\n\nKey Features:\n\u2022 Only three probabilistic pair sources with amplitudes [\u03b1, \u03b2, \u03b1].  \n\u2022 removed_connections = [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]] to enforce SSH graph.  \n\u2022 anc_detectors = [1,2] perform the Bell\u2010measurements.  \n\u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] between the chosen input/output modes.  \n\u2022 By sweeping \u03b2/\u03b1 externally and recording heralding rates for 0\u21923 versus 3\u21920, one obtains a directional teleportation matrix whose asymmetry \u201cswitches\u201d at \u03b2=\u03b1\u2014the SSH topological transition.\n\nPytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Directional teleportation on a 4\u2010site SSH chain',\n  'foldername': 'SSH_directional_teleport',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 20,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'amplitudes': ['\u03b1','\u03b2','\u03b1'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n  'anc_detectors': [1,2],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNext Steps for the Expert:\n1. Scanning \u03c6\u2208[0,2\u03c0) at fixed \u03b2/\u03b1>1 yields a quantized, 2\u03c0-periodic pumping probability P_pump(\u03c6) whose total 2\u03c0-phase winding equals the Floquet-SSH topological invariant.\n\nNetwork Structure:\n\nLayer 1:  \n  S\u2081(\u03b1): 0\u27f71\u2003S\u2082(\u03b2\u2009e^{i\u03c6}): 1\u27f72\u2003S\u2083(\u03b1): 2\u27f73  \n         \u2198Bell\u2005M\u2081      \u2198Bell\u2005M\u2082  \n         det 1        det 2  \n\nLayer 2:  \n  S\u2084(\u03b1): 0\u27f71\u2003S\u2085(\u03b2): 1\u27f72\u2003S\u2086(\u03b1): 2\u27f73  \n         \u2198Bell\u2005M\u2083      \u2198Bell\u2005M\u2084  \n         det 3        det 4  \n\nAncilla clicks {det 1,2,3,4} herald the relocated Bell pair on modes (2,3).  \n\nKey Results:\n\u2022 For \u03b2/\u03b1<1, P_pump(\u03c6)=0 \u2200\u03c6 (trivial regime).  \n\u2022 For \u03b2/\u03b1>1, P_pump(\u03c6)\u2009>\u20090 only when \u03c6 winds; plotting P_pump vs. \u03c6 shows a single 2\u03c0 winding in \u03c6\u2014the Floquet-SSH topological invariant.  \n\u2022 A direct, measurement-induced 2D topological invariant in a purely static photon network.\n\nPytheus-style Config Sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Floquet-SSH entanglement pump with synthetic phase drive',\n  'foldername': 'SSH_Floquet_phase_pump',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 50,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 4,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 20,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'amplitudes': ['\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03c6)','\u03b1','\u03b1','\u03b2','\u03b1'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n  'anc_detectors': [1,2,3,4],\n  'imaginary': True,\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNext Steps:\n1. By performing two interior Bell\u2010state measurements (ancilla detectors at modes 1 and 2), an unknown qubit is teleported from mode 0 to mode 3. The heralded teleportation fidelity \nF(\u03b2/\u03b1,\u03b8) = Prob[Bell pair | clicks at ancilla]\ndirectly tracks the Fubini\u2013Study metric of the SSH two\u2010band eigenstates as a function of both parameters. By scanning \u03b2/\u03b1 and \u03b8 externally and recording F, one can reconstruct the metric tensor g_{ij} = Re[\u3008\u2202_i\u03c8|\u2202_j\u03c8\u3009\u2212\u3008\u2202_i\u03c8|\u03c8\u3009\u3008\u03c8|\u2202_j\u03c8\u3009] of the SSH manifold\u2014mapping out local curvature and detecting critical points at \u03b2/\u03b1=1.\n\nVisualization:\n\n   Pair sources:      0 \u27f7 1          1 \u27f7 2          2 \u27f7 3  \n                      S\u2081(\u03b1)           S\u2082(\u03b2\u00b7e^{i\u03b8})    S\u2083(\u03b1)\n                            \u2198Bell M\u2081     \u2198Bell M\u2082\n                             det 1        det 2\n\n  Input qubit on mode 0 \u2192 teleported to mode 3 on ancilla clicks.\n\nKey Features:\n\u2022 Probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources only; three sources with complex amplitudes ['\u03b1','\u03b2\u00b7exp(i*\u03b8)','\u03b1'].  \n\u2022 removed_connections = [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]] enforce the 1D SSH connectivity.  \n\u2022 anc_detectors = [1,2] perform two Bell\u2010swap measurements.  \n\u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] between modes [0,3] conditioned on ancilla clicks.  \n\u2022 By external sweeps of (\u03b2/\u03b1,\u03b8) and measuring F(\u03b2/\u03b1,\u03b8), one obtains the full quantum metric of a topological SSH band\u2014fusing \u201cquantum metric\u201d and \u201cSSH chain\u201d in a pure teleportation network without state\u2010generation or feedback.\n\nSuggested Pytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n\n{\n  'description': 'SSH\u2010chain teleportation for quantum\u2010metric tomography',\n  'foldername': 'SSH_qmetric_tel',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 25,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'imaginary': True,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'amplitudes': ['\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03b8)','\u03b1'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n  'anc_detectors': [1,2],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNext Steps:\n1.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201cquantum metric\u201d and \u201cSSH chain\u201d in a Pytheus-compatible quantum-network:\n    1) Teleportation-fidelity scan on a 3-bond SSH chain to extract Fubini\u2013Study metric from the curvature of the end-to-end teleportation fidelity.\n    2) Heralded on/off teleportation as a binary indicator of the SSH winding number.\n    3) Swap-test quantum-metric tomography: teleport two unknown qubits via two parallel SSH chains at slightly different coupling ratios (\u03b2/\u03b1 and \u03b2/\u03b1+\u0394), then perform a linear-optical swap-test on the outputs to directly measure their overlap |\u3008\u03c8\u2081|\u03c8\u2082\u3009|\u00b2\u22481\u2013\u0394\u00b2g, thus retrieving the quantum metric g of the SSH band.\n  Step 2: Quick feasibility & novelty:\n    \u2022 (1) & (2) collapse to simple fidelity or on/off swapping\u2014already critiqued.\n    \u2022 (3) uniquely uses two teleportation channels + an interferometric swap test to directly measure the quantum metric of a topological band\u2014no prior photon-network proposals do this.\n    \u2022 It uses only probabilistic pair-sources, static beam-splitters, and photon-number detectors. No dynamic feedback or forbidden elements.\n  Step 3: Select idea (3): Swap-test quantum-metric tomography via parallel SSH teleporters.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because it fuses entanglement-swapping teleportation over SSH-connectivity graphs with a photon-based swap test to directly measure the local Fubini\u2013Study metric of a two-band topological model\u2014something never done in linear-optical networks.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because:\n    \u2022 We only need to optimize two identical teleportation networks (\u201cSSH teleporter\u201d) and one fixed swap-test interferometer.\n    \u2022 Each SSH teleporter uses three probabilistic pair sources with amplitudes ['\u03b1','\u03b2\u00b7e^{i\u03b8}','\u03b1'], two ancilla detectors for the Bell measurements, and removed_connections to enforce the intracell/intercell bonds.\n    \u2022 The swap test is just a balanced beam splitter between the two teleported photons and two detectors.\n    \u2022 All elements\u2014pair sources, beam splitters, phase shifters, single-photon detectors\u2014are within Pytheus\u2019s scope.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for the Expert:\n\nTitle:\nSwap-Test Quantum-Metric Tomography of an SSH Band via Parallel Teleportation Channels\n\nGoal:\nConstruct two parallel entanglement-swapping teleporters\u2014each realizing a three-bond SSH chain (modes 0\u20131\u20132\u20133) with intracell amplitude \u03b1 and intercell amplitude \u03b2\u2009e^{i\u03b8}\u2014to teleport two unknown qubit states |\u03c8(k)\u3009 and |\u03c8(k+\u0394k)\u3009 from mode 0 to mode 3. After heralded teleportation, the two output photons interfere on a balanced beam splitter (the swap test) followed by coincidence detectors. The probability P\u209b\u209c(\u0394k) of coincident clicks gives |\u3008\u03c8(k)|\u03c8(k+\u0394k)\u3009|\u00b2\u22481\u2212\u0394k\u00b2g(k), thus directly retrieving the Fubini\u2013Study quantum metric g(k) of the SSH band.\n\nNetwork Structure:\n\nParallel Teleporters (identical up to \u0394k):\n  For i=1,2:\n    Pair sources S\u1d62\u2081(\u03b1): mode 0\u21941  \n                 S\u1d62\u2082(\u03b2\u00b7e^{i\u03b8\u1d62}): mode 1\u21942  \n                 S\u1d62\u2083(\u03b1): mode 2\u21943  \n          \u2198Bell M\u1d62\u2081   \u2198Bell M\u1d62\u2082  \n          det\u1d62\u2081      det\u1d62\u2082  \n    m\u1d62_out = teleported qubit on mode 3\n\nSwap-Test:\n  m\u2081_out & m\u2082_out \u2192 50:50 beam splitter \u2192 detectors D\u208a, D\u208b  \n  Coincidence rate \u221d \u00bd[1\u2212|\u3008\u03c8\u2081|\u03c8\u2082\u3009|\u00b2]\n\nProcedure:\n1. Prepare two input qubits |\u03c8(k)\u3009 and |\u03c8(k+\u0394k)\u3009 at modes 0 of Teleporter 1 and Teleporter 2, choosing \u03b8\u2081=k, \u03b8\u2082=k+\u0394k externally.  \n2. Herald teleportation by two-click events at det\u1d62\u2081 & det\u1d62\u2082 for each i.  \n3. Interfere the two teleported photons at the central beam splitter, record coincidence probability P\u209b\u209c(\u0394k).  \n4. From P\u209b\u209c(\u0394k) \u2248 1\u2212\u0394k\u00b2g(k), extract the local quantum metric g(k).\n\nKey Pytheus Features:\n\u2022 Two independent SSH teleporters with \u201camplitudes\u201d: ['\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03b8\u2081)','\u03b1'] and ['\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03b8\u2082)','\u03b1'].  \n\u2022 removed_connections = [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]] in each teleporter.  \n\u2022 anc_detectors = [det\u2081\u2081,det\u2081\u2082] and [det\u2082\u2081,det\u2082\u2082] for the two Bell-swaps.  \n\u2022 A fixed 50:50 beam splitter and two detectors for the swap test.  \n\u2022 No dynamic feedback, no cavities, no forbidden state generation\u2014purely static linear optics + post-selection.\n\nSuggested Pytheus-style config sketch:\n\n{\n 'description': 'Swap-test quantum-metric tomography via parallel SSH teleporters',\n 'foldername': 'SSH_swaptest_qmetric',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n 'edges_tried': 30,\n 'ftol': 1e-06,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 4,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 10,\n 'imaginary': True,\n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],   # Bell herald per teleporter\n 'amplitudes': ['\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03b8\u2081)','\u03b1','\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03b8\u2082)','\u03b1'],\n 'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n 'anc_detectors': [1,2,3,4],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNext Steps:\n\u2022 Hand off this abstract network to Pytheus to find beam-splitter parameters for each teleporter.  \n\u2022 In the lab, fix \u03b2/\u03b1 and \u03b8\u2081=k, sweep \u0394k = \u03b8\u2082\u2212\u03b8\u2081 small, record P\u209b\u209c(\u0394k).  \n\u2022 From the quadratic decline in P\u209b\u209c, reconstruct g(k), mapping the quantum metric of the SSH band without any state generation or dynamic control.\n\nThis protocol realizes for the first time a direct quantum-network measurement of a topological band\u2019s Fubini\u2013Study metric by combining entanglement-swapping over SSH graphs with a linear-optical swap test\u2014an experimentally accessible, purely linear-optical quantum-metric tomography."

Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. By heralding the projector onto the PT-modified Bell state (the target map) and tuning its gain/loss parameter \u03b3, the protocol controllably generates a two-photon output |\u03a8_AD\u27e9\u221d|HH\u27e9+\u03b3\u2009e^{i\u03d5}|VV\u27e9 with adjustable, non-maximal entanglement.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposal for the Expert. We simulate a four-site SSH chain via a linear-optical entanglement-swapping network. \u2028By constraining which pair sources can emit to which modes, we enforce the alternating \u201cintracell\u201d (0\u20131, 2\u20133) and \u201cintercell\u201d (1\u20132) couplings of the SSH model. Bell measurements at modes 1 and 2 then teleport (swap) entanglement from the left boundary (mode 0) to the right boundary (mode 3). Heralding on the two ancilla detector clicks implements a teleportation channel\u2014effectively a Bell state\u2014between modes 0 and 3. Varying the connectivity or ancilla patterns will let one probe the topological protection of this teleportation.\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to create a maximally entangled state |\u03a6+> = |00>+|11> (without normalization) between end modes 0 and 3, using only probabilistic photon-pair sources and linear optics. No single emitter sends to more than two nodes. Two interior nodes (1 and 2) serve as ancilla detectors performing joint Bell measurements that herald the end-to-end entanglement. By forbidding direct pair sources on the \u201cwrong\u201d edges (removed_connections), we encode the SSH alternating coupling:\n\u2022 Intracell: sources connect (0\u21941) and (2\u21943).  \n\u2022 Intercell: source connects (1\u21942).  \n\u2022 Forbidden: no sources on (0\u21942), (0\u21943), or (1\u21943).\n\nThis network:\n\u2022 Realizes an SSH chain in abstract mode-connectivity.  \n\u2022 Implements multi-node entanglement swapping \u2192 teleportation.  \n\u2022 Tests the topological robustness of the teleportation channel (quantum metric of boundary vs bulk couplings).  \n\u2022 Is fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: uses only pair sources, linear optics, ancilla detectors, and post-selection.   \n\nProposed Pytheus config:\n\n{'description': 'Topologically-protected teleportation on a four-site SSH chain via entanglement swapping',\n 'foldername': 'SSH_teleport',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n 'edges_tried': 30,\n 'ftol': 1e-06,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 2,\n 'num_pre': 1,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'imaginary': False,\n 'safe_hist': True,\n 'samples': 10,\n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n 'thresholds': [0.2,0.1],\n 'single_emitters': [],\n 'tries_per_edge': 5,\n 'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n 'unicolor': True,\n 'number_resolving': True,\n 'anc_detectors': [1,2]\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The core mechanism here is simply entanglement swapping across three Bell pairs (sources on 0\u20131, 1\u20132, 2\u20133) with Bell\u2010measurements on the middle nodes to teleport entanglement to the ends. That is essentially the same primitive as \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d in the known list. Labelling the link pattern as an \u201cSSH chain\u201d does not introduce a new quantum-optical target or nontrivial topological Hamiltonian dynamics\u2014there is no genuine protection or bulk\u2010edge gap being simulated, only a fixed connectivity graph and post\u2010selected teleportation fidelity measurement. As stated, this is a straightforward rephrasing of three\u2010pair entanglement swapping and does not reach the bar for a genuinely novel, publishable PRL proposal. Action: reject  \nAction Input: The proposal reduces to Bell\u2010swap teleportation over three linked photon\u2010pair sources\u2014equivalent to the \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d experiment on your exclusion list. Simply calling the graph \u201cSSH\u201d without engineering a true topological Hamiltonian, probing a gap, or demonstrating genuine robustness beyond ordinary entanglement\u2010swap fidelity does not yield a new quantum\u2010optical target. The quantized \u201coff\u2192on\u201d jump at \u03b2/\u03b1=1 is a direct photon-network demonstration of the Floquet-SSH winding number\u2014a novel, purely measurement-induced topological invariant without state generation or dynamic control.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The scheme remains a sequence of standard entanglement\u2010swapping layers with static probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources and post\u2010selection. By heralding sequential Bell swaps in each layer, an initial Bell pair on (0,1) is pumped to (2,3) in two quantized steps\u2014but only when both \u03b2/\u03b1\u2009>\u20091 and the Floquet phase \u03c6 winds the band structure around the origin. Scanning \u03c6\u2208[0,2\u03c0) at fixed \u03b2/\u03b1>1 yields a quantized, 2\u03c0-periodic pumping probability P_pump(\u03c6) whose total 2\u03c0-phase winding equals the Floquet-SSH topological invariant.\n\nNetwork Structure:\n\nLayer 1:  \n  S\u2081(\u03b1): 0\u27f71\u2003S\u2082(\u03b2\u2009e^{i\u03c6}): 1\u27f72\u2003S\u2083(\u03b1): 2\u27f73  \n         \u2198Bell\u2005M\u2081      \u2198Bell\u2005M\u2082  \n         det 1        det 2  \n\nLayer 2:  \n  S\u2084(\u03b1): 0\u27f71\u2003S\u2085(\u03b2): 1\u27f72\u2003S\u2086(\u03b1): 2\u27f73  \n         \u2198Bell\u2005M\u2083      \u2198Bell\u2005M\u2084  \n         det 3        det 4  \n\nAncilla clicks {det 1,2,3,4} herald the relocated Bell pair on modes (2,3).  \n\nKey Results:\n\u2022 For \u03b2/\u03b1<1, P_pump(\u03c6)=0 \u2200\u03c6 (trivial regime).  \n\u2022 For \u03b2/\u03b1>1, P_pump(\u03c6)\u2009>\u20090 only when \u03c6 winds; plotting P_pump vs. \u03c6 shows a single 2\u03c0 winding in \u03c6\u2014the Floquet-SSH topological invariant.  \n\u2022 A direct, measurement-induced 2D topological invariant in a purely static photon network.\n\nPytheus-style Config Sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Floquet-SSH entanglement pump with synthetic phase drive',\n  'foldername': 'SSH_Floquet_phase_pump',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 50,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 4,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 20,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'amplitudes': ['\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03c6)','\u03b1','\u03b1','\u03b2','\u03b1'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n  'anc_detectors': [1,2,3,4],\n  'imaginary': True,\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNext Steps:\n1. By performing two interior Bell\u2010state measurements (ancilla detectors at modes 1 and 2), an unknown qubit is teleported from mode 0 to mode 3. The heralded teleportation fidelity \nF(\u03b2/\u03b1,\u03b8) = Prob[Bell pair | clicks at ancilla]\ndirectly tracks the Fubini\u2013Study metric of the SSH two\u2010band eigenstates as a function of both parameters. By scanning \u03b2/\u03b1 and \u03b8 externally and recording F, one can reconstruct the metric tensor g_{ij} = Re[\u3008\u2202_i\u03c8|\u2202_j\u03c8\u3009\u2212\u3008\u2202_i\u03c8|\u03c8\u3009\u3008\u03c8|\u2202_j\u03c8\u3009] of the SSH manifold\u2014mapping out local curvature and detecting critical points at \u03b2/\u03b1=1.\n\nVisualization:\n\n   Pair sources:      0 \u27f7 1          1 \u27f7 2          2 \u27f7 3  \n                      S\u2081(\u03b1)           S\u2082(\u03b2\u00b7e^{i\u03b8})    S\u2083(\u03b1)\n                            \u2198Bell M\u2081     \u2198Bell M\u2082\n                             det 1        det 2\n\n  Input qubit on mode 0 \u2192 teleported to mode 3 on ancilla clicks.\n\nKey Features:\n\u2022 Probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources only; three sources with complex amplitudes ['\u03b1','\u03b2\u00b7exp(i*\u03b8)','\u03b1'].  \n\u2022 removed_connections = [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]] enforce the 1D SSH connectivity.  \n\u2022 anc_detectors = [1,2] perform two Bell\u2010swap measurements.  \n\u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] between modes [0,3] conditioned on ancilla clicks.  \n\u2022 By external sweeps of (\u03b2/\u03b1,\u03b8) and measuring F(\u03b2/\u03b1,\u03b8), one obtains the full quantum metric of a topological SSH band\u2014fusing \u201cquantum metric\u201d and \u201cSSH chain\u201d in a pure teleportation network without state\u2010generation or feedback.\n\nSuggested Pytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n\n{\n  'description': 'SSH\u2010chain teleportation for quantum\u2010metric tomography',\n  'foldername': 'SSH_qmetric_tel',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 25,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'imaginary': True,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'amplitudes': ['\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03b8)','\u03b1'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n  'anc_detectors': [1,2],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNext Steps:\n1. After heralded teleportation, the two output photons interfere on a balanced beam splitter (the swap test) followed by coincidence detectors. The probability P\u209b\u209c(\u0394k) of coincident clicks gives |\u3008\u03c8(k)|\u03c8(k+\u0394k)\u3009|\u00b2\u22481\u2212\u0394k\u00b2g(k), thus directly retrieving the Fubini\u2013Study quantum metric g(k) of the SSH band.\n\nNetwork Structure:\n\nParallel Teleporters (identical up to \u0394k):\n  For i=1,2:\n    Pair sources S\u1d62\u2081(\u03b1): mode 0\u21941  \n                 S\u1d62\u2082(\u03b2\u00b7e^{i\u03b8\u1d62}): mode 1\u21942  \n                 S\u1d62\u2083(\u03b1): mode 2\u21943  \n          \u2198Bell M\u1d62\u2081   \u2198Bell M\u1d62\u2082  \n          det\u1d62\u2081      det\u1d62\u2082  \n    m\u1d62_out = teleported qubit on mode 3\n\nSwap-Test:\n  m\u2081_out & m\u2082_out \u2192 50:50 beam splitter \u2192 detectors D\u208a, D\u208b  \n  Coincidence rate \u221d \u00bd[1\u2212|\u3008\u03c8\u2081|\u03c8\u2082\u3009|\u00b2]\n\nProcedure:\n1. Prepare two input qubits |\u03c8(k)\u3009 and |\u03c8(k+\u0394k)\u3009 at modes 0 of Teleporter 1 and Teleporter 2, choosing \u03b8\u2081=k, \u03b8\u2082=k+\u0394k externally.  \n2. Herald teleportation by two-click events at det\u1d62\u2081 & det\u1d62\u2082 for each i.  \n3. Interfere the two teleported photons at the central beam splitter, record coincidence probability P\u209b\u209c(\u0394k).  \n4. From P\u209b\u209c(\u0394k) \u2248 1\u2212\u0394k\u00b2g(k), extract the local quantum metric g(k).\n\nKey Pytheus Features:\n\u2022 Two independent SSH teleporters with \u201camplitudes\u201d: ['\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03b8\u2081)','\u03b1'] and ['\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03b8\u2082)','\u03b1'].  \n\u2022 removed_connections = [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]] in each teleporter.  \n\u2022 anc_detectors = [det\u2081\u2081,det\u2081\u2082] and [det\u2082\u2081,det\u2082\u2082] for the two Bell-swaps.  \n\u2022 A fixed 50:50 beam splitter and two detectors for the swap test.  \n\u2022 No dynamic feedback, no cavities, no forbidden state generation\u2014purely static linear optics + post-selection.\n\nSuggested Pytheus-style config sketch:\n\n{\n 'description': 'Swap-test quantum-metric tomography via parallel SSH teleporters',\n 'foldername': 'SSH_swaptest_qmetric',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n 'edges_tried': 30,\n 'ftol': 1e-06,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 4,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 10,\n 'imaginary': True,\n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],   # Bell herald per teleporter\n 'amplitudes': ['\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03b8\u2081)','\u03b1','\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03b8\u2082)','\u03b1'],\n 'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n 'anc_detectors': [1,2,3,4],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNext Steps:\n\u2022 Hand off this abstract network to Pytheus to find beam-splitter parameters for each teleporter.  \n\u2022 In the lab, fix \u03b2/\u03b1 and \u03b8\u2081=k, sweep \u0394k = \u03b8\u2082\u2212\u03b8\u2081 small, record P\u209b\u209c(\u0394k).  \n\u2022 From the quadratic decline in P\u209b\u209c, reconstruct g(k), mapping the quantum metric of the SSH band without any state generation or dynamic control.\n\nThis protocol realizes for the first time a direct quantum-network measurement of a topological band\u2019s Fubini\u2013Study metric by combining entanglement-swapping over SSH graphs with a linear-optical swap test\u2014an experimentally accessible, purely linear-optical quantum-metric tomography.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This protocol, at its heart, is just two parallel runs of the standard three\u2010pair entanglement\u2010swapping chain followed by a familiar optical swap\u2010test.  There is no new interference beyond Bell\u2013swap coincidences, and the extraction of the Fubini\u2013Study metric via post\u2010processing of teleportation fidelities does not introduce a genuinely new quantum\u2010optical target.  It all reduces to \u201cEntanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs\u201d (done twice) plus a routine swap\u2010test\u2014well within the exclusion list\u2014and so fails to reach the bar for a genuinely novel, PRL-worthy experiment.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The core network is identical to known multi-pair entanglement-swapping setups, and the swap-test is a textbook fidelity measurement.     "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Field test of mode-pairing quantum key distribution\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Efficient algorithms for simulating percolation in photonic fusion\n  networks\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Accelerating the training of single-layer binary neural networks using\n  the HHL quantum algorithm\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. BEFORE CREATING AN IDEA, THINK ABOUT WHETHER MY PREVIOUS FEEDBACK WOULD ALLOW IT!!!\n\nBe constructively critical of your own idea and check if it is novel. Refine it and aim for producing a truly novel idea.\n\nHere are the targets that pytheus has already designed quantum optics experiments for.  A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"quantum metric\" and \"ssh chain\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Teleportation-fidelity mapping of the SSH quantum metric: a three-bond chain with adjustable intracell (\u03b1) and intercell (\u03b2) source amplitudes; two Bell measurements in the interior teleport a qubit end\u2192end. Scanning \u03b2/\u03b1 yields fidelity F(\u03b2/\u03b1), whose curvature gives the Fubini\u2013Study metric of the SSH band.\n  2. Measurement-induced detection of SSH edge modes: build a four-site SSH chain (\u03b1\u2013\u03b2\u2013\u03b1 bonds), perform only two interior Bell measurements and postselect on end-to-end entanglement. In the topological regime (\u03b2>\u03b1) ends become entangled; in the trivial regime (\u03b2<\u03b1) cancellation prevents teleportation. The sudden appearance of heralded entanglement is a measurement-based winding-number indicator.\n  3. Resource-count phase detector: vary the number of ancilla Bell measurements required to teleport a qubit across an N-site alternating chain; the minimal ancilla count jumps at the SSH topological transition.  \nStep 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n  1. Fidelity-mapping (idea 1) is really just scanning fidelity\u2014too close to prior feedback.  \n  2. Edge-mode entanglement (idea 2) is purely a network, not state generation, and uses the existence or absence of teleportation as a topological order parameter. It goes beyond mere fidelity scanning and encodes a winding-number signature via a binary entanglement/no-entanglement output.  \n  3. Resource-count (idea 3) is abstract and less direct, and might be hard to phrase as one Pytheus target.  \nStep 3: Pick idea 2 as most promising.\nStep 4: Novelty: No prior linear-optical entanglement-swapping experiment has used a two-measurement teleportation protocol whose success vanishes in the trivial SSH regime and appears only above the topological threshold. This binary \u201cteleportation on/off\u201d constitutes a measurement-induced topological invariant test, not just fidelity or state generation.  \nStep 5: Feasibility:  \n  \u2022 Pure network protocol: three probabilistic photon-pair sources, static beam-splitters with amplitude weights \u03b1,\u03b2, two ancilla Bell detectors, no feedback or cavities.  \n  \u2022 Pytheus can optimize such a network with \u201camplitudes\u201d for sources and \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to enforce the SSH graph, plus \u201canc_detectors\u201d to herald the swap.  \n  \u2022 The Expert can externally choose \u03b1<\u03b2 or \u03b1>\u03b2 and observe heralded coincidence rates \u2192 zero vs nonzero.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for the Expert:\n\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Detection of SSH Edge Modes via Binary Teleportation\n\nGoal:\nRealize a four-mode SSH chain (modes 0\u20131\u20132\u20133) in an entanglement-swapping network. Three probabilistic photon-pair sources provide bonds 0\u20131 (amplitude \u03b1), 1\u20132 (\u03b2), and 2\u20133 (\u03b1). Two interior nodes (1 and 2) perform Bell-state measurements (ancilla detectors). We herald a Bell pair between the end modes 0 and 3. The key is that in the trivial regime (\u03b2<\u03b1) destructive interference cancels all paths \u2192 zero heralding rate (no end-to-end teleportation), whereas in the topological regime (\u03b2>\u03b1) a robust nonzero heralding rate appears. The abrupt \u201coff\u2192on\u201d behaviour as \u03b2 crosses \u03b1 is a measurement-induced winding-number signature of the SSH model.\n\nVisualization:\n   Source S\u2081(\u03b1)       S\u2082(\u03b2)        S\u2083(\u03b1)\n   mode 0 \u27f7 mode 1 \u2014 mode 1 \u27f7 mode 2 \u2014 mode 2 \u27f7 mode 3\n         \u2198 Bell M\u2081      \u2198 Bell M\u2082\n           det 1           det 2\n   Heralded clicks at det 1&2 \u21d2 entangled output between modes 0 & 3\n\nKey Features:\n\u2022 Only probabilistic pair sources + static linear optics.  \n\u2022 Source amplitudes [\u03b1,\u03b2,\u03b1] realize the SSH intracell/intercell pattern.  \n\u2022 removed_connections:[[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]] enforce no unwanted bonds.  \n\u2022 anc_detectors: [1,2] perform Bell measurements.  \n\u2022 target_quantum:['00','11'] between output modes [0,3].  \n\u2022 In Pytheus: you ask for a setup that gives a maximally entangled Bell pair at modes 0&3 conditioned on clicks at ancilla detectors.  \n\u2022 The Expert then varies \u03b2/\u03b1 externally to observe the heralding probability jump at the topological transition.\n\nSuggested Pytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'SSH edge\u2010mode detector via binary teleportation',\n  'foldername': 'SSH_edge_teleport',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 20,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'amplitudes': ['\u03b1','\u03b2','\u03b1'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n  'anc_detectors': [1,2],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNext Steps:\n1. Fidelity\u2010mapping teleportation: scan \u03b2/\u03b1 on a single\u2010cycle SSH chain and extract the quantum metric from the curvature of the end\u2010to\u2010end teleportation fidelity.\n    2. Measurement\u2010induced topological on/off teleport: observe a binary herald rate for teleportation over a static SSH graph, using its \u201coff\u2192on\u201d switch at \u03b2=\u03b1 as a winding\u2010number indicator.\n    3. Floquet entanglement pumping: implement two successive \u201cSSH\u201d coupling layers in one static linear\u2010optical network to realize a Floquet cycle that pumps an entangled Bell pair from one end of a 4\u2010mode chain to the other in quantized fashion. Each layer alternates intracell/intercell couplings (\u03b1,\u03b2,\u03b1), and two ancilla Bell measurements mediate the pump. A second identical layer completes the unit quantum pump, transferring the entangled pair from modes (0,1) to (2,3). The quantized, stepwise relocation of the pair is a direct network\u2010level topological invariant (pumping winding number), not just fidelity or on/off coincidence.\n  Step 2: Novelty & feasibility check:\n    1 & 2 have been deemed too close to simple swapping or fidelity scans.  \n    3 is novel: no linear\u2010optical network has realized quantized entanglement pumping or a Floquet\u2010SSH cycle via static multi\u2010layer swapping.  \n    Feasible: uses only pair sources, static BS layers, and post\u2010selective Bell measurements\u2014well within Pytheus.\n  Step 3: Select idea 3: Floquet entanglement pump.\n  Step 4: Novelty: It\u2019s the first proposal to simulate a Floquet\u2010driven SSH pump in a purely linear\u2010optical, entanglement\u2010swapping network, achieving quantized relocation of a Bell pair as a topological invariant.\n  Step 5: Feasibility in Pytheus:\n    \u2022 All elements are static photon\u2010pair sources (six in total), beam splitters, and ancilla detectors\u2014no feedback or cavities.  \n    \u2022 We express two coupling layers by grouping sources into \u201cLayer 1\u201d (0\u20131:\u03b1, 1\u20132:\u03b2, 2\u20133:\u03b1) and \u201cLayer 2\u201d (re\u2010apply 0\u20131:\u03b1,1\u20132:\u03b2,2\u20133:\u03b1) interleaved with Bell\u2010swap measurements at modes 1 and 2.  \n    \u2022 removed_connections enforce SSH connectivity; ancilla detectors [1,2] herald each swap.  \n    \u2022 The final target is a Bell pair between modes 2 and 3 conditioned on four ancilla clicks\u2014teleporting the original entanglement from 0\u21923 in two quantized steps.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposal for the Expert:\n\nTitle: Floquet\u2010SSH Entanglement Pump: Quantized Bell\u2010Pair Relocation in a Static Linear\u2010Optical Network\n\nGoal:\nDesign a 4\u2010mode, two\u2010layer entanglement\u2010swapping network that realizes one full Floquet cycle of an SSH pump. After heralded teleportation, the two output photons interfere on a balanced beam splitter (the swap test) followed by coincidence detectors. The probability P\u209b\u209c(\u0394k) of coincident clicks gives |\u3008\u03c8(k)|\u03c8(k+\u0394k)\u3009|\u00b2\u22481\u2212\u0394k\u00b2g(k), thus directly retrieving the Fubini\u2013Study quantum metric g(k) of the SSH band.\n\nNetwork Structure:\n\nParallel Teleporters (identical up to \u0394k):\n  For i=1,2:\n    Pair sources S\u1d62\u2081(\u03b1): mode 0\u21941  \n                 S\u1d62\u2082(\u03b2\u00b7e^{i\u03b8\u1d62}): mode 1\u21942  \n                 S\u1d62\u2083(\u03b1): mode 2\u21943  \n          \u2198Bell M\u1d62\u2081   \u2198Bell M\u1d62\u2082  \n          det\u1d62\u2081      det\u1d62\u2082  \n    m\u1d62_out = teleported qubit on mode 3\n\nSwap-Test:\n  m\u2081_out & m\u2082_out \u2192 50:50 beam splitter \u2192 detectors D\u208a, D\u208b  \n  Coincidence rate \u221d \u00bd[1\u2212|\u3008\u03c8\u2081|\u03c8\u2082\u3009|\u00b2]\n\nProcedure:\n1. Prepare two input qubits |\u03c8(k)\u3009 and |\u03c8(k+\u0394k)\u3009 at modes 0 of Teleporter 1 and Teleporter 2, choosing \u03b8\u2081=k, \u03b8\u2082=k+\u0394k externally.  \n2. Herald teleportation by two-click events at det\u1d62\u2081 & det\u1d62\u2082 for each i.  \n3. Interfere the two teleported photons at the central beam splitter, record coincidence probability P\u209b\u209c(\u0394k).  \n4. From P\u209b\u209c(\u0394k) \u2248 1\u2212\u0394k\u00b2g(k), extract the local quantum metric g(k).\n\nKey Pytheus Features:\n\u2022 Two independent SSH teleporters with \u201camplitudes\u201d: ['\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03b8\u2081)','\u03b1'] and ['\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03b8\u2082)','\u03b1'].  \n\u2022 removed_connections = [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]] in each teleporter.  \n\u2022 anc_detectors = [det\u2081\u2081,det\u2081\u2082] and [det\u2082\u2081,det\u2082\u2082] for the two Bell-swaps.  \n\u2022 A fixed 50:50 beam splitter and two detectors for the swap test.  \n\u2022 No dynamic feedback, no cavities, no forbidden state generation\u2014purely static linear optics + post-selection.\n\nSuggested Pytheus-style config sketch:\n\n{\n 'description': 'Swap-test quantum-metric tomography via parallel SSH teleporters',\n 'foldername': 'SSH_swaptest_qmetric',\n 'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n 'edges_tried': 30,\n 'ftol': 1e-06,\n 'loss_func': 'cr',\n 'num_anc': 4,\n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n 'samples': 10,\n 'imaginary': True,\n 'target_quantum': ['00','11'],   # Bell herald per teleporter\n 'amplitudes': ['\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03b8\u2081)','\u03b1','\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03b8\u2082)','\u03b1'],\n 'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n 'anc_detectors': [1,2,3,4],\n 'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNext Steps:\n\u2022 Hand off this abstract network to Pytheus to find beam-splitter parameters for each teleporter.  \n\u2022 In the lab, fix \u03b2/\u03b1 and \u03b8\u2081=k, sweep \u0394k = \u03b8\u2082\u2212\u03b8\u2081 small, record P\u209b\u209c(\u0394k).  \n\u2022 From the quadratic decline in P\u209b\u209c, reconstruct g(k), mapping the quantum metric of the SSH band without any state generation or dynamic control.\n\nThis protocol realizes for the first time a direct quantum-network measurement of a topological band\u2019s Fubini\u2013Study metric by combining entanglement-swapping over SSH graphs with a linear-optical swap test\u2014an experimentally accessible, purely linear-optical quantum-metric tomography.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core network is identical to known multi-pair entanglement-swapping setups, and the swap-test is a textbook fidelity measurement.  To be novel, you must propose a quantum-optical architecture or measurement that cannot be decomposed into back-to-back Bell-swap channels and standard interferometry\u2014for instance, by engineering nontrivial multi-photon interference beyond pairwise swaps, or by implementing an actively driven or non-Hermitian synthetic bandstructure whose topological invariant is read out in a way irreducible to simple teleportation plus swap test.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Here is the proposal for the Expert:\n\nTitle:\nSuperposed\u2010SSH Teleportation Network for Direct Quantum\u2010Metric Tomography\n\nGoal:\nImplement two parallel SSH\u2010chain teleporters in coherent superposition so that a single photonic qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 is split, teleported through two slightly different SSH couplings, recombined, and interfered. The interference visibility between the two teleported outputs directly yields the Fubini\u2013Study overlap |\u27e8\u03c8\u2081|\u03c8\u2082\u27e9| and hence the local quantum metric of the SSH band.\n\nNetwork Overview:\n\n1) Single\u2010Photon Source & Splitter  \n   \u2013 A single\u2010photon emitter prepares the unknown qubit in a dual\u2010rail encoding on mode 0.  \n   \u2013 A 50:50 beamsplitter BS\u2080 splits it into two paths: mode 0a and mode 0b.\n\n2) Two SSH Teleporters (A and B) in Superposition  \n   For i\u2208{A,B}, teleporter i uses three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources S\u1d621,S\u1d622,S\u1d623 with amplitudes  \n     [\u03b1,\u2009\u03b2\u00b7e^{i\u03b8\u1d62},\u2009\u03b1]  \n   connecting modes:  \n     0i \u27f7 1i  (amplitude \u03b1)  \n     1i \u27f7 2i  (amplitude \u03b2\u2009e^{i\u03b8\u1d62})  \n     2i \u27f7 3i  (amplitude \u03b1)  \n   Two ancilla detectors at modes 1i and 2i perform Bell\u2010swap measurements (detectors det\u1d621, det\u1d622), heralding the teleportation of the qubit from mode 0i to mode 3i.\n\n   \u2013 Teleporter A: \u03b8_A = k  \n   \u2013 Teleporter B: \u03b8_B = k + \u0394k  \n\n3) Recombiner & Interference  \n   \u2013 Outputs at modes 3a and 3b recombine on a second 50:50 beamsplitter BS\u2081.  \n   \u2013 Two detectors D\u208a, D\u208b record which output port the photon exits.  \n   \u2013 Condition on all four ancilla clicks (det_A1,det_A2,det_B1,det_B2) plus a click at D\u208a or D\u208b.  \n   \u2013 The probability difference  \n       V(\u0394k) = [P(D\u208a)\u2013P(D\u208b)] \u221d Re\u2009\u27e8\u03c8(k)|\u03c8(k+\u0394k)\u27e9  \n     yields the overlap. For small \u0394k,  \n       V(\u0394k) \u2243 1 \u2013 \u00bd\u2009(\u0394k)\u00b2\u2009g(k)  \n     so the quantum metric g(k) of the SSH two\u2010band eigenstates is read off from the quadratic drop.\n\nKey Features & Why It\u2019s Novel:\n\u2022   We are not simply swapping or doing a swap\u2010test post\u2010selected on two independent teleports; instead, we place two distinct SSH teleportation channels into genuine quantum superposition, then interfere them.  \n\u2022   This superposition\u2010of\u2010networks architecture lets us directly measure the Fubini\u2013Study overlap\u2014and thus the quantum metric\u2014of a topological band without requiring separate channel tomography or external swap tests.  \n\u2022   The two branches differ only by a small parameter shift \u0394k in the complex intercell phase, so scanning \u0394k directly probes the local geometry of the SSH band manifold.  \n\u2022   All operations are static, linear\u2010optical, and purely post\u2010selected: one single\u2010photon emitter, six probabilistic pair sources, four ancilla Bell measurements, two 50:50 beam splitters, and final detectors. No dynamic feedback, no cavities, and no forbidden state\u2010generation.\n\nSuggested Pytheus\u2010style Config Sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Superposed SSH teleportation for quantum\u2010metric tomography',\n  'foldername': 'SSH_superpose_qmetric',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 4,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 20,\n  'imaginary': True,\n  'single_emitters': [0],            # single\u2010photon source at mode 0\n  'pair_sources': [1,2,3,4,5,6],     # six pair sources\n  'amplitudes': ['\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*k)','\u03b1', '\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*(k+\u0394k))','\u03b1'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0a,2a],[0a,3a],[1a,3a],[0b,2b],[0b,3b],[1b,3b]],\n  'anc_detectors': [1a,2a,1b,2b],\n  'intersplitters': [{'modes':[0,0a,0b],'ratios':[1,1,1]},  # BS0\n                     {'modes':[3a,3b,7,8],'ratios':[1,1,1]}], # BS1 \u2192 det 7,8\n  'number_resolving': True,\n  'target_quantum': ['clicks at detectors 1a,2a,1b,2b,7 or 8']\n}\n\nNext Steps:\n1) Feed this abstract superposition\u2010of\u2010networks target into Pytheus to find the explicit beam\u2010splitter and phase\u2010shifter settings.  \n2) In the lab, fix \u03b1, vary \u03b2 and k, choose a small \u0394k, and scan k. For each k: record the four ancilla\u2010click herald plus interference visibility V(\u0394k).  \n3) Fit V(\u0394k) \u2243 1\u2013\u00bd(\u0394k)\u00b2\u2009g(k) to reconstruct the quantum metric g(k) of the SSH band.  \n\nThis protocol realizes the first purely linear\u2010optical, post\u2010selected quantum network that measures a topological\u2010band quantum metric via coherent superposition of distinct entanglement\u2010swapping channels\u2014no state\u2010generation, no dynamic control, and well within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities."

In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. Teleportation-fidelity mapping of the SSH quantum metric: a three-bond chain with adjustable intracell (\u03b1) and intercell (\u03b2) source amplitudes; two Bell measurements in the interior teleport a qubit end\u2192end. Scanning \u03b2/\u03b1 yields fidelity F(\u03b2/\u03b1), whose curvature gives the Fubini\u2013Study metric of the SSH band.\n  2. Measurement-induced detection of SSH edge modes: build a four-site SSH chain (\u03b1\u2013\u03b2\u2013\u03b1 bonds), perform only two interior Bell measurements and postselect on end-to-end entanglement. In the topological regime (\u03b2>\u03b1) ends become entangled; in the trivial regime (\u03b2<\u03b1) cancellation prevents teleportation. The sudden appearance of heralded entanglement is a measurement-based winding-number indicator.\n  3. Resource-count phase detector: vary the number of ancilla Bell measurements required to teleport a qubit across an N-site alternating chain; the minimal ancilla count jumps at the SSH topological transition.  \nStep 2: Quick novelty/feasibility check:\n  1. Fidelity-mapping (idea 1) is really just scanning fidelity\u2014too close to prior feedback.  \n  2. Edge-mode entanglement (idea 2) is purely a network, not state generation, and uses the existence or absence of teleportation as a topological order parameter. It goes beyond mere fidelity scanning and encodes a winding-number signature via a binary entanglement/no-entanglement output.  \n  3. Three probabilistic photon-pair sources provide bonds 0\u20131 (amplitude \u03b1), 1\u20132 (\u03b2), and 2\u20133 (\u03b1). Two interior nodes (1 and 2) perform Bell-state measurements (ancilla detectors). We herald a Bell pair between the end modes 0 and 3. The key is that in the trivial regime (\u03b2<\u03b1) destructive interference cancels all paths \u2192 zero heralding rate (no end-to-end teleportation), whereas in the topological regime (\u03b2>\u03b1) a robust nonzero heralding rate appears. Three probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources provide bonds 0\u20131 (\u03b1), 1\u20132 (\u03b2), and 2\u20133 (\u03b1). Two interior modes (1 and 2) perform Bell measurements (ancilla detectors). We prepare an unknown qubit on one end and attempt to teleport it to the other:\n\n\u2022 Forward channel: mode 0\u2192mode 3  \n\u2022 Reverse channel: mode 3\u2192mode 0  \n\nIn the trivial phase (\u03b2<\u03b1) teleportation succeeds only in the reverse direction; in the topological phase (\u03b2>\u03b1) it flips\u2014only the forward channel works. The sharp change of success\u2010rate asymmetry at \u03b2=\u03b1 is a direct network\u2010level signature of the SSH winding number.\n\nVisualization:\n   S\u2081(\u03b1)       S\u2082(\u03b2)       S\u2083(\u03b1)\n  mode 0\u27f7mode 1\u2014mode 1\u27f7mode 2\u2014mode 2\u27f7mode 3\n         \u2198Bell M\u2081     \u2198Bell M\u2082\n         det 1        det 2\nCase A: input qubit at 0 \u21d2 attempt teleport to 3; heralded by clicks at {det 1, det 2}.  \nCase B: input at 3 \u21d2 attempt teleport to 0; same ancilla measurement.\n\nKey Features:\n\u2022 Only three probabilistic pair sources with amplitudes [\u03b1, \u03b2, \u03b1].  \n\u2022 removed_connections = [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]] to enforce SSH graph.  \n\u2022 anc_detectors = [1,2] perform the Bell\u2010measurements.  \n\u2022 target_quantum = ['00','11'] between the chosen input/output modes.  \n\u2022 By sweeping \u03b2/\u03b1 externally and recording heralding rates for 0\u21923 versus 3\u21920, one obtains a directional teleportation matrix whose asymmetry \u201cswitches\u201d at \u03b2=\u03b1\u2014the SSH topological transition.\n\nPytheus\u2010style config sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Directional teleportation on a 4\u2010site SSH chain',\n  'foldername': 'SSH_directional_teleport',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 20,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'amplitudes': ['\u03b1','\u03b2','\u03b1'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n  'anc_detectors': [1,2],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNext Steps for the Expert:\n1. Scanning \u03c6\u2208[0,2\u03c0) at fixed \u03b2/\u03b1>1 yields a quantized, 2\u03c0-periodic pumping probability P_pump(\u03c6) whose total 2\u03c0-phase winding equals the Floquet-SSH topological invariant.\n\nNetwork Structure:\n\nLayer 1:  \n  S\u2081(\u03b1): 0\u27f71\u2003S\u2082(\u03b2\u2009e^{i\u03c6}): 1\u27f72\u2003S\u2083(\u03b1): 2\u27f73  \n         \u2198Bell\u2005M\u2081      \u2198Bell\u2005M\u2082  \n         det 1        det 2  \n\nLayer 2:  \n  S\u2084(\u03b1): 0\u27f71\u2003S\u2085(\u03b2): 1\u27f72\u2003S\u2086(\u03b1): 2\u27f73  \n         \u2198Bell\u2005M\u2083      \u2198Bell\u2005M\u2084  \n         det 3        det 4  \n\nAncilla clicks {det 1,2,3,4} herald the relocated Bell pair on modes (2,3).  \n\nKey Results:\n\u2022 For \u03b2/\u03b1<1, P_pump(\u03c6)=0 \u2200\u03c6 (trivial regime).  \n\u2022 For \u03b2/\u03b1>1, P_pump(\u03c6)\u2009>\u20090 only when \u03c6 winds; plotting P_pump vs. \u03c6 shows a single 2\u03c0 winding in \u03c6\u2014the Floquet-SSH topological invariant.  \n\u2022 A direct, measurement-induced 2D topological invariant in a purely static photon network.\n\nPytheus-style Config Sketch:\n{\n  'description': 'Floquet-SSH entanglement pump with synthetic phase drive',\n  'foldername': 'SSH_Floquet_phase_pump',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.0,\n  'edges_tried': 50,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 4,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 20,\n  'target_quantum': ['00','11'],\n  'amplitudes': ['\u03b1','\u03b2*exp(i*\u03c6)','\u03b1','\u03b1','\u03b2','\u03b1'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n  'anc_detectors': [1,2,3,4],\n  'imaginary': True,\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNext Steps:\n1. After heralded teleportation, the two output photons interfere on a balanced beam splitter (the swap test) followed by coincidence detectors. The probability P\u209b\u209c(\u0394k) of coincident clicks gives |\u3008\u03c8(k)|\u03c8(k+\u0394k)\u3009|\u00b2\u22481\u2212\u0394k\u00b2g(k), thus directly retrieving the Fubini\u2013Study quantum metric g(k) of the SSH band.\n\nNetwork Structure:\n\nParallel Teleporters (identical up to \u0394k):\n  For i=1,2:\n    Pair sources S\u1d62\u2081(\u03b1): mode 0\u21941  \n                 S\u1d62\u2082(\u03b2\u00b7e^{i\u03b8\u1d62}): mode 1\u21942  \n                 S\u1d62\u2083(\u03b1): mode 2\u21943  \n          \u2198Bell M\u1d62\u2081   \u2198Bell M\u1d62\u2082  \n          det\u1d62\u2081      det\u1d62\u2082  \n    m\u1d62_out = teleported qubit on mode 3\n\nSwap-Test:\n  m\u2081_out & m\u2082_out \u2192 50:50 beam splitter \u2192 detectors D\u208a, D\u208b  \n  Coincidence rate \u221d \u00bd[1\u2212|\u3008\u03c8\u2081|\u03c8\u2082\u3009|\u00b2]\n\nProcedure:\n1.
